text: hi welcome everybody so I'm sho hung I'm
the director of ecosystem at the cloud
native computing foundation and today
I'm going to talk about how the
kubernetes community has grown to its
present state what's the role of open
source foundation like the CN CF and
what does it actually do and then I'm
going to look at some trends that we've
seen through 2019 and some upcoming
challenges from 2020 so kubernetes is
one of the highest velocity open source
projects ever this graph plots the top
30 projects across three axes so the
x-axis is the number of commits the
y-axis is the number of pull requests
and issues and then the size of the
bubble represents the number of authors
so Linux is the purple bubble to the top
right hand corner and kubernetes is the
pink circle that's sort of to the left
of that in the top middle but kubernetes
is where if not unique in the open
source world and that it was defined
very early on as both a project and a
community and the complete community
looks like this kubernetes is made up of
1.1 million contributions from 35,000
contributors and more than 2,000
contributing companies and what we're
seeing over time is that these companies
are getting more and more diverse so
initially Google and Red Hat made up 85%
of contributors today they make up
around 35% as other companies have been
getting involved the same is true of the
countries that the contributors are
located in so the USA originally made up
about 80 to 85 percent of contributors
today that's about 40% and I would love
if this bubble for Australia in New
Zealand also was bigger the next time we
come here
so the CNC F is a neutral home that
hosts these open-source projects so my
perspective is that I was originally an
engineer at Google so I was building
features on top of Google Maps and
deploying it using Borg and Borg later
inspired kubernetes so my mission at the
CN CF is to now drive the adoption of
these projects by working primarily with
end-users but in practice I think the
CNC F does things that open-source
developers don't want to do themselves
so we provide marketing we run events
like this one
we provide continuous integration
resources for testing do security audits
hire technical writers to do
documentation and translations and we
hold the legal trademarks for these
projects as well
and every year we also run regular
surveys to take the pulse of the
community and see what challenges are
coming up and these numbers that I'm
about to show you have not been
published anywhere so these are a sneak
preview of some of the numbers for 2019
so the results of this come from about
1100 responses about 65% of whom are
software engineers or sis admins the
rest sort of managers directors and so
on so you probably won't be surprised to
know that containers a pretty mainstream
and 85% of people said that they were
running containers in production but
large container deployments are
increasingly common so 19 percent of
people said they run more than 5,000
containers
15 percent said that they run more than
5,000 machines
that's bare metal or virtual machines
and 10 percent even said they run more
than 50 clusters and the top challenges
the respondents said that they're facing
are the cultural changes to work with
the development team security as Liz
just spoke about the complexity of the
overall solution
and then a lack of training and
expertise so here are some of the other
challenges that people face logging
monitoring storage and so on and what I
want to show here is that over time
these challenges are slowly going down
so each bar represents surveys from 2016
2017 2018 but overall the the trend is
going down as more tools and more
resources are available for people to
solve these challenges some of these
include CN CF projects and we're seeing
that kubernetes prometheus container d
chord e NS and Envoy are showing
increases in production since 2018 and
fluent D G RPC Jaeger and linker D are
roughly stable compared to 2018 and a
little bit more detail about how people
are managing complexity 44% people said
they use service service mesh 70% of
auto-scaling 50% using serverless on the
other hand most cloud native storage
options are lagging behind so we're
seeing that people are evaluating
storage but they're not yet running
things like open EBS or work or other
storage projects in evaluation and let
me pause here and ask how many people
are running how many people are
evaluating containers or kubernetes at
the moment maybe it's 10% how many
people are running all their stateless
stateless applications within Cuba
Nettie's ok probably a quarter third how
many people were running the stake for
applications as well ok probably about
another quarter ok that doesn't add up
to 100% but never mind ok so the upshot
of this is that 55% are saying that they
release at least daily or weekly
and 80% have at least automated
partially or fully their release process
so I think this is a positive trend
towards a guitar smaadahl we're doing
smaller and more frequent releases so
some takeaways for you
cloud native deployments they're getting
larger they're getting more
sophisticated the most common challenge
now is actually working with the stock
with their developer teams and making
the changes needed within the
organization and lastly the increased
release automation is paying off and we
are seeing this smaller more frequent
release cycle we're going to publish a
lot more numbers in the next month or so
a couple of weeks so look forward to
that on the CNC F blog these slides are
available on my blog at osho comm thank
you very much
[Applause]
